title.narrative: Humanitarian response to displacement resulting from conflict in Mrauk U District

description.narrative: Support to strengthen the organisational and technical capacity of local CSOs to effectively deliver humanitarian assistance; and to help meet the needs of currently displaced IDPs in Mrauk U District.

mailing-address.narrative: 31–35 Kirby St, Holborn, London, England EC1N 8TE

description.narrative: 1st fund received for 7401- requested £124,597.00 on Oct 10th 2019 ; USD value received $161,461.51 on Nov 1st 2019
2nd fund received for 7401- requested £161,422.00 on 3rd Feb 2020 ; USD value received $209,538.67 on 12th Feb 2020
Final Payment request for 7401- requested £113,981.00 on 24th Sep 2020 ; USD value received $ 145,230.03 on 14th Oct 2020

title.narrative: Output 2.1

description.narrative: CSOs mapped for technical capacity needs

title.narrative: Number of technical capacity assessments carried out

comment.narrative: Target for Year 1
24 CSOs participated in OCA exercise
Target for Year 1
24 CSOs participated in OCA exercise.
Target for Year 1

During the reporting period, RI mapped 26 CSOs (MraukU-13, Myebon-9, Minbya-3 and Kyauk Taw-1) (see Table2). The mapping focus was to provide an overview for operational CSOs in the four targeted townships.
Target for Year 1
To be reported on in subsequent quarters.

title.narrative: Output 2.2

description.narrative: CSOs receive technical capacity building training in, inter alia, protection, humanitarian principles, SPHERE standards

title.narrative: Number of participants in technical trainings delivered in protection, humanitarian principles, SPHERE standards

description.narrative: Number of participants in technical trainings delivered in protection, humanitarian principles, SPHERE standards

comment.narrative: Target for Year 1
55 (45 participants for CHS/Humanitarian Principle, SPHRE standards and 10 in Protection)
Target for Year 1
65 CSOs volunteers (29 M and 36 F) participants for CHS/Humanitarian Principles, SPHRE standards
Target for Year 1
80 CSO staffs (39 male & 41 females) benefitted from these trainings
Target for Year 1
Basic Child Protection and Protection Sexual Exploitation & Abuse workshop in Myebon was attended by 10 CSO volunteers representing 5 CSOs.
Target for Year 1
To be reported on in subsequent quarters.

title.narrative: Output 1.2

description.narrative: CSOs receive training in building organisational capacity

title.narrative: Number of participants in trainings, mentoring visits, on-the-job support visits to CSOs

description.narrative: Number of participants in trainings, mentoring visits, on-the-job support visits to CSOs

comment.narrative: Target for Year 1
1 training on distribution process was carried out in Mrauk U to 12 CSO staff of 4 CSOs, and on the job distribution learning experience to 41 CSO staff from 7 CSOs was conducted
Target for Year 1
177 CSO volunteers (50% women) received organizational development training
Target for Year 1
26 CSO staff received M&E training in Mrauk U; 8 CSO staff received CCCM Site profile data collection; 46 CSO staff received training in Humanitarian SPHERE Standards/CHS.
Target for Year 1

61 CSO volunteers (50% women) received training in COVID-19 Homebased Quarantine& Awareness, PDM, and ChildProtection &/PSEA& Policies/SOPs duringthe reporting period, There were 24 formal engagements with CSOs.
Target for Year 1
CSOs volunteers (123 M and 116 F) received organizational development training

title.narrative: Output 3.1

description.narrative: Displaced communities consulted on urgent humanitarian needs by local humanitarian actors

title.narrative: Number of needs assessments carried out by CSOs

description.narrative: Number of needs assessments carried out by CSOs

comment.narrative: 10 needs assessments were carried out by CSOs, including CCCM monthly camp profile, hygiene kits, and dignity kits, and COVID-19 distributions.
CCCM monthly camp profile, hygiene kits, and dignity kits,and COVID-19 distributions
CSOs carried out 2 needs assessments for newly arrived in Mrauk U and Myebon IDP sites.
CSOs carried out 2 needs assessments for newly arrived in Mrauk U and Myebon IDP sites.
To be reported on in subsequent quarters.

title.narrative: Output 3.2

description.narrative: Displaced communities receive urgent humanitarian assistance through NFIs and/or cash, delivered by local humanitarian actors

title.narrative: Number of distributions carried out by local CSOs

description.narrative: Number of distributions carried out by local CSOs

comment.narrative: Target for Year 1

4 Distributions: 1. MUYA distributions:14IDP sites (Mrauk U), 2. UNHCR NFIs (1 kit/ HH): 2 IDP sites (Myebon), HP-KITS: 2 IDP sites (Myebon), 3. UNFPA DIGNITY KITS: 5 IDP sites (Mrauk U), 4 IDP sites (Myebon), 4. UNHCR BLANKETS: 11 IDP sites (Mrauk U), 4 IDP sites (Myebon)
Target for Year 1
4 NFI distributions were conducted in Mrauk U & Myebon
Target for Year 1
During the reporting period, the CSO MUYA conducted 1 NFI distribution.
Target for Year 1
The CSO partners have supported 21 NFI distributions in 16 IDP sites, coordinating with UNHCR, UNFPA, and other partners.
Target for Year 1

title.narrative: Outcome 3

description.narrative: IDPs receiving timely assistance to meet urgent humanitarian needs

title.narrative: # of IDPs reached with humanitarian assistance (NFIs and/or cash distributions)

description.narrative: Counts those displaced receiving humanitarian assistance by RI or partner CSOs

comment.narrative: 13,478 IDPs were reached.

actual.value: 4 Distributions done: (1) MUYA distributions (Mrauk U): sleeping sets and kitchen kits to 196 HHS, kitchen kits to 336 HH, big community cooking pots to 27 HHs UNHCR NFI kits to 162 HHs. (2) UNHCR NFIs (1 kit/ HH): 328 Individuals (Myebon), HP-KITS (1 kit/HH): 328 Individuals (Myebon). (3) UNFPA DIGNITY KITS (1 kit per female age 12+yrs): 934 females age 12 years + (Mrauk U and Myebon), (4) UNHCR BLANKETS (2 blankets/ HH): 3,460 individuals in Mrauk U and Myebon)

comment.narrative: 4 Distributions done: 1) MUYA distributions (Mrauk U): sleeping sets and kitchen kits to 196 HHS, kitchen kits to 336 HH, big community cooking pots to 27 HHs UNHCR NFI kits to 162 HHs. 2) UNHCR NFIs (1 kit/ HH): 328 Individuals (Myebon), HP-KITS (1 kit/ HH): 328 Individuals (Myebon), 3) UNFPA DIGNITY KITS (1 kit per female age 12+yrs) : 934 females age 12 years + (Mrauk U and Myebon), 4) UNHCR BLANKETS (2 blankets/ HH): 3460 individuals in Mrauk U and Myebon)
4 distributions and two COVID-19 response distributions reached 6,824 IDPs.
Two distributions reached: 833 HH (a population of 2,818) in 11 IDP sites in Mrauk Uand77 HH (246 people)in Myebon. In total, project reached 3,064 IDPs in this reporting period.

title.narrative: % of issues raised by community members addressed

description.narrative: Numerator: counts number of issues raised followed up, action points recorded and fed back to community members Denominator: counts number of issues raised and logged in complaints and feedback database

comment.narrative: Estimate linked to the community feedback and subsequent distributions.
NFI requests made through complaint response mechanism -CRM -boxes that RI and CSO partners were able to respond to. In addition, during winter a need for blankets was identified and addressed.
This is the % of NFI requests made through CRM boxes that RI and CSO partners were able to respond to.
To be reported on in subsequent quarters.
To be reported on in subsequent reporting periods.

description.narrative: Numerator: counts number of people displaced receiving cash assistance Denominator: Counts number of people displaced receiving humanitarian assistance

title.narrative: Impact

description.narrative: Persons displaced by conflict in Mrauk U District, Rakhine State have access to appropriate and efficient humanitarian support delivered by local CSOs

title.narrative: % of targeted beneficiaries reporting access to timely and appropriate humanitarian assistance

description.narrative: Numerator: Counts # of beneficiaries reporting 'timely'* and 'appropriate'* humanitarian assistance. Denominator: Counts # of beneficiaries receiving humanitarian assistance by CSOs and/or RI for the duration of the project

comment.narrative: A PDM carried out at the end of Q.2 reporting period suggests that high percentage of satisfaction. Only one PDM was able to take place in Q4
A PDM carried out at the end of last reporting period suggests that high percentage of satisfaction.It was not possible to carry out a PDM during this reporting period.
A PDM carried out at the end of reporting period suggests that high percentage of satisfaction.
To be measured in subsequent reporting periods.
To be measured in subsequent reporting periods.

title.narrative: % of CSO-led humanitarian interventions that are based on an evidence-based needs assessment

description.narrative: Numerator: Counts # of humanitarian project interventions led by CSOs for which needs assessments are carried out in advance of response Denominator: Counts # project interventions responding to humanitarian emergencies led by CSOs within the timeframe/scope of the project

comment.narrative: All the distributions were carried out in line with needs assessments
During the reporting period all the distributions were carried out in line needs assessments.
During the reporting period all the distributions were carried out in line needs assessments.
To be measured in subsequent reporting periods.
To be measured in subsequent reporting periods.

title.narrative: % of CSOs demonstrating improvements in humanitarian programme management

description.narrative: Numerator: Counts # of target CSOs with defined* procedures/accountability measures. Denominator: Counts # of target CSOs participating in capacity development programme

comment.narrative: 22 CSOs participated in Humanitarian Principles & CHS workshops and 5 CSOs participated in Protection workshop). The assessment is based on pre-and post-test evaluations. HI mapped 28 CSOs.
22 CSOs participated in Humanitarian Principles & CHS workshops and 5 CSOs participated in Protection workshop). The assessment is based on pre-and post-test evaluations. HI mapped 29 CSOs.
During the reporting period, 11 CSOs participated in the organizational Policy & SOP training. And the project mapped 24 CSOs. The assessment is based on pre-and post-test evaluations

title.narrative: Outcome 2

description.narrative: Selected CSOs with technical capacity to assess and respond to humanitarian emergencies

title.narrative: # of CSO-led humanitarian responses informed by humanitarian/protection principles, and/or SPHERE standards

description.narrative: Counts humanitarian responses to conflict/displacement led by CSOs which are designed in line with i) SPHERE standards; ii) humanitarian principles; iii) protection principles

comment.narrative: 1 CSO-led humanitarian response during the reporting period was informed by humanitarian/protection principles, and/or SPHERE standards
21 CSO-led humanitarian responses during the reporting period were informed by humanitarian/protection principles, and/or SPHERE standards
28 distributions

title.narrative: % of humanitarian responses/distributions plans that are sensitive to needsaccording to gender, disability and vulnerability criteria

description.narrative: Numerator: number of responses (NFIs, cash) based on population data and vulnerability criteria from needs assessments and township data Denominator: number of humanitarian responses carried out during the project timeline

comment.narrative: According to the PDM carried out in all 14 IDP sites, 100% of of humanitarian responses/distributions plans were sensitive to needsaccording to gender, disability and vulnerability criteria
According to the PDM carried out in all 14 IDP sites, 100% of of humanitarian responses/distributions plans were sensitive to needsaccording to gender, disability and vulnerability criteria.
